key_points: Former President Donald Trump filed class-action lawsuits against Facebook, Twitter, and Google over social media bans.
The lawsuits target the tech giants and their CEOs: Mark Zuckerberg, Jack Dorsey, and Sundar Pichai respectively.
Trump's legal actions demand restoration of his social media accounts and punitive damages to prevent bans on other users.
The legal effort is led by John P. Coale, familiar with lawsuits against big tobacco companies.
Trump's bans from Twitter, Facebook, and YouTube came after the January 6 Capitol riot.
Tech platforms and advocacy groups have rejected Trump's claims, citing First Amendment protections.
NetChoice CEO Steve DelBianco criticized the action, emphasizing the First Amendment's protection of media from the president.
The lawsuits challenge Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act, attempting to label social media companies as government actors.
Trump's lack of access to major social media platforms has impacted his online presence, though he's increasing public activities.
A federal judge recently blocked a Florida law that would prevent social media platforms from banning political candidates.
